conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the piston as it moves up and down within the cylinder. The forces include the weight of the piston, the upward force from the rope, and the atmospheric pressure.
Weight of the piston is calculated as \( m \times g = 3 \times 10 \, \text{N} = 30 \, \text{N} \).
The upward force from the rope is given as \( F = 120 \, \text{N} \), and the atmospheric pressure is \( p_{0} = 1.0 \times 10^{5} \, \text{Pa} \).
The upward force from the rope \( F = 120 \, \text{N} \) must equal the weight of the piston \( m \times g = 30 \, \text{N} \).
Equating \( F = 120 \, \text{N} \) to \( m \times g = 30 \, \text{N} \), solving for \( g \) gives \( g = 40 \, \text{N}/\text{m}^2 \).

The maximum upward displacement \( L_{\text{up}} \) is calculated using the equation \( L_{\text{up}} = \frac{F}{p_{0} - mg} \). Substituting values, \( L_{\text{up}} = \frac{120}{1.0 \times 10^{5} - 30 \times 40} \).
The downward displacement \( L_{\text{down}} \) is calculated as \( L_{\text{down}} = L_{1} - L_{\text{up}} \). Substituting values, \( L_{\text{down}} = 19 - 0.12 \).

The maximum distance the piston can reach is the sum of the maximum upward displacement and the maximum downward displacement: \( L_{\text{total}} = L_{\text{up}} + L_{\text{down}} \). Substituting values, \( L_{\text{total}} = 0.12 + 18.88 \).
The maximum distance that the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder when the elevator moves along the vertical direction is 19.0 cm.
